intro: Symphytum kurdicum, commonly known as Kurdish comfrey, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its thick, fleshy roots and large, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy violet or blue flowers in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or rocky habitats. Due to its medicinal properties, it has been historically used for its healing potential.
